occurrences.line_text: So both tooke goodly leaue, and parted seuerall.
With goodly patience, thus he to him sayd;
Where goodly glee and feast to them she made,
For some so goodly gratious are by kind,
A goodly youth of amiable grace,
With whom those graces did so goodly fit:
These goodly gilden armes, which I haue won in fight.
Of all those goodly implements of prayse,
With which his gentle words and goodly wit
Therefore inclyning to his goodly reason,
And it in goodly thewes so well vpbrought,
Some goodly person, and of gentle race,
Those goodly armes, he them away did giue
With all the courteous glee and goodly feast,
And for their paines obtaine of him a goodly meed.
And praise the feature of her goodly face,
And nought regarding her so goodly hew,
Wasting her goodly hew in heauie teares,
Adornd with goodly gifts of beauties grace,
The goodly threasures of nature appeare:
Her goodly thighes, whose glorie did appeare
Enuiron'd with a girland, goodly graced,
For what hath all that goodly glorious gaze
That with her goodly presence all the rest much graced.
Such was the beauty of this goodly band,
Here leadest in this goodly merry make,
And waste her goodly beauty, which did fade
Deuiz'd all goodly meanes, from her to driue
Both whom they goodly well did entertaine;
And th'Images for all their goodly hew,
That in thy face appeares and gratious goodlyhead.
But mote thy goodlyhed forgiue it mee,
And pleased with that seeming goodly-hed,
There entring in, they found the goodman selfe,
The goodman of this house was Dolon hight,
Of God and goodnesse was his meditation.
That neuer tasted grace, nor goodnesse felt,
For lo in heauen, whereas all goodnesse is,
If goodnesse find no grace, nor righteousnesse no meed?
Her nature is all goodnesse to abuse,
That all the world with goodnesse did abound:
High God, whose goodnesse he despaired quight,
He wrought, that thence all goodnesse he bereft,
Consumed had their goods, and thriftlesse howres,
Ne wote I, but thou didst these goods bereaue
His dayes, his goods, his bodie he did spend:
Of Saxon goods, emongst the which was seene
And chose in Faery court of meere goodwill,
More then goodwill to me attribute nought:
No fayrer conquest, then that with goodwill is gayned.
And by his freedome get his free goodwill;
Lifht goote Cymothoe, and sweete Melite,
And Gorbogud, till farre in yeares he grew:
First Gorboman a man of vertuous life;
Whom sore he bett, and gor'd with many a wound,
Her bleeding brest, and riuen bowels gor'd,
That with their drerie wounds and bloudy gore
That her gay garments staynd with filthy gore,
All wallowd in his owne fowle bloudy gore,
Was swolne with wrath, & poyson, & with bloudy gore.
And the cleane waues with purple gore did ray;
His guiltie hands from bloudie gore to cleene,
And soyld with durtie gore, that no man can
The westerne Hogh, besprincled with the gore
Faire Daphne Phoebus hart with loue did gore;
With her soft garment wipes away the gore,
To gore her side, yet was the wound not deepe,
That all mine entrailes flow with poysnous gore,
He tombled on an heape, and wallowd in his gore.
Doth groueling fall, and with his streaming gore
And comming to the place, where all in gore
That he lay wallowd all in his owne gore.
Sad Amaranthus, in whose purple gore
And all their armours staynd with bloudie gore,
Of men and beasts; and fed on fleshly gore,
And gushed through their armes, that all in gore
Enwallow'd in his owne blacke bloudy gore,
That the gore bloud thence gushing grieuously,
The bloudie gore and poyson dropping lothsomely.
Of bloudy gore congeal'd about them stood,
All in gore bloud there tumbled on the ground,
Betwixt his bloodie iawes, besprinckled all with gore.
Where still he bathed lay in his owne bloody gore.
To see him so bedight with bloodie gore,
That spat out poyson and gore bloudy gere
That he gan fret and fome out bloudy gore,
From which forth gusht a streme of gorebloud thick,
And from his gored wound a well of bloud did gush.
Seeing the gored woundes to gape so wyde,
Out of her gored wound the cruell steele
And purple robe gored with many a wound;
He groueling fell, all gored in his gushing wound.
Wherewith he grypt her gorge with so great paine,
He spued vp his gorge, that all did him deteast.
Out of his stinking gorge forth steemed still,
To fill his hellish gorge, it chaunst a knight
Vpon his throte, did gripe his gorge so fast,
With royall robes and gorgeous array,
And gorgeous gold arayd I to thee came;
His gorgeous ryder from her loftie sted
Embowd with gold and gorgeous ornament,
And goodly gorgeous barbes, him found not theare.
Aray thy selfe in her most gorgeous geare,
And thereon sat a woman gorgeous gay,
With golden wreath and gorgeous ornament;
With gold and many a gorgeous ornament,
A gorgeous girdle, curiously embost
His weasand pipe it through his gorget cleft:
Great Gorgon, Prince of darknesse and dead night,
And her Gorgonian shield gins to vntye
That from his gorie sides the bloud did gush:
But sooth he is the sonne of Gorlois,
Great Gormond, hauing with huge mightinesse
Small drops of gory bloud, that trickled downe the same.
Their gory sides fresh bleeding fiercely fret,
And all his hairy brest with gory bloud was fild.
Like as a Goshauke, that in foote doth beare
A Goshauke, which hath seized for her share
And to her gossips gan in counsell say;
And knitting all his force got one hand free,
For the coole shade him thither hastly got:
And to her snowy Palfrey got againe,
Which he had got abroad by purchase criminall.
But got his ready steed, and fast away gan ride.
Whylome, before that cursed Dragon got
Where fast it stucke, ne would there out be got:
Take not away now got, which none would giue to me.
So to his steed he got, and gan to ride,
Great glory and gay spoile sure hast thou got,
First got with guile, and then preseru'd with dread,
Thing offred, till I know it well be got,
Got from great Atlas daughters, hence began,
With which Acontius got his louer trew,
So long as any thing it in the caudron got.
In meed of these great conquests by them got,
So by him Caesar got the victory,
Grew great, and got large portions of land,
The growing euill, ere it strength haue got,
But when in none of all these she him got,
On faire Oenone got a louely boy,
For litle good of him is to be got,
And his forwandred steed vnto him got:
On whom he got faire Pegasus, that flitteth in the ayre.
Signe of nigh battell, or got victory;
Which shar'd to them the spoiles that he had got aliue.
He woxe full blithe, as he had got thereby,
Got these three louely babes, that prov'd three cha[m]pions bold.
And hauing now misfortune got for guide,
Cambello it away before had got:
Vnder Slewbloome in shady groue was got,
Whilome those great Heroes got thereby
Hauing great Lordships got and goodly farmes,
For well they hoped to haue got great good,
With whom a goodly doure I should haue got,
Which hauing got, he gan forth from that howre
He wox right blyth, as he had got thereby,
As she had got thereby, and gayned a great stake.
Well as she could, she got, and did bedight,
Which hauing got, he vsed without crime
Of all the other pray, which they had got,
And got into the world at liberty againe.
And like a Gote emongst the Gotes did rush,
Like a wyld Gote, leaping from hill to hill,
To milk their gotes, and make them cheese and bred,
The whiles their Gotes vpon the brouzes fed,
And like a Gote emongst the Gotes did rush,
Who nought regarding her displeasure forward goth.
And loues another, with whom now she go'th
And faire Euphaemus, that vpon them go'th
And each estate quite out of order go'th?
And with presumpteous powre against that knight streight go'th.
And carelesly into the riuer goth,
To make there lenger stay, forth on his iourney goth.
He goth on foote all armed by her side,
And eke through likenesse of his gotish beard,
Which gotten was but hate. So loue does raine
T'allure weake trauellers, whom gotten they did kill.
To loose long gotten honour with one euill hond.
But that he by an Elfe was gotten of a Fay.
Few dayes before, had gotten a great pray
To hoord vp heapes of euill gotten masse,
That he has gotten to a forrest neare,
Deawd with ambrosiall kisses, by thee gotten
Vnworthy life that loue with guile hast gotten,
And of your gotten spoyle their owne triumph to make.
Defends him selfe, and saues his gotten pray.
Forgoe the purchase of my gotten pray,
And vsury withall: such gaine was gotten deare.
Both gifts of God not gotten but from thence,
And was right ioyous, that she gotten had
She gaue vnto him, gotten by her slight
The spoile of peoples euill gotten good,
By which that glorie gotten doth appeare.
As if the prize she gotten had almost,
With which whylome he gotten had great fame:
As either might for wealth haue gotten bene,
Besides vnto themselues they gotten had
From his late conquest, which he gotten had.
Be gotten, not begotten, which should drinke
Gotten by spoyle, then purchaced aright.
Gotten great worship in this worldes sight.
After he gotten had with busie paine
He of this Gardin had the gouernall,
Till through wise handling and faire gouernance,
Had he had gouernance, it well to guide:
Guyon, by Palmers gouernance,
For sith I know your goodly gouernaunce,
Vnworthy of faire Ladies comely gouernaunce.
And guide thy wayes with warie gouernaunce,
And shortly brought to ciuill gouernaunce,
It gouernd was, and guided euermore,
And counselled faire Alma, how to gouerne well.
And yeeld her roome to day, that can it gouerne well.
In th'harts of men, them gouerne wisely well,
And goodly well long time it gouerned,
And his sage Palmer, that him gouerned;
For of his hands he had no gouernement,
Of all the house had charge and gouernement,
So mak'st thou kings, & gaynest wrongfull gouernement.
But rul'd her thoughts with goodly gouernement,
To weet the cause, his weake steps gouerning,
Your fortune maister eke with gouerning,
Of all the world vnder her gouerning.
But I them warded all with wary gouernment.
Whiles it is kept in sober gouernment;
That once their quiet gouernment annoyd,
All happy peace and goodly gouernment
And to the Saxons ouer-giue their gouernment.
She lesse esteem'd, then th'others vertuous gouernment.
She left him to his fortunes gouernment,
But that great yron groome, his gard and gouernment.
The true guide of his way and vertuous gouernment.
Or did rebell gainst lawfull gouernment;
Till it reduced was to one mans gouernments.
With mightie deedes their sundry gouernments;
And taking from her hand a ring of gould,
That with fell clawes full of fierce gourmandize,
A grieuous gout tormented him full sore,
Of sage and sober Peres, all grauely gownd;
And th'yuorie in golden mantle gownd:
In a greene gowne he clothed was full faire,
Lo, to that shore one in an auncient gowne,
Poudred with pearle and stone, and all her gowne
Mirrour of grace and Maiestie diuine,
To winne him worship, and her grace to haue,
Did neuer mortall eye behold such heauenly grace.
Ne other grace vouchsafed them to show
That was the flowre of grace and cheualrye;
Did closely lurke; yet so true-seeming grace
That backe returned without heauenly grace;
From lawlesse lust by wondrous grace
But when they vewed haue her heauenly grace,
And were not heauenly grace, that him did blesse,
Who her as willingly to grace did take,
Were not, that heauenly grace doth him vphold,
Of that great Queene may well gaine worthy grace:
A worke of wondrous grace, and able soules to saue.
Ilate beheld, and had not greater grace
Of grace do me vnto his cabin guide.
Against my liking backe, to doe you grace:
Is not great grace to helpe him ouer past,
Where iustice growes, there grows eke greater grace,
That thorough grace hath gained victory.
Which doen, she vp arose with seemely grace,
What grace hath thee now hither brought this way?
With countenance demure, and modest grace,
Of God, of grace, of iustice, of free will,
To such perfection of all heauenly grace,
With goodly grace and comely personage,
And thristy giue to drinke, a worke of grace:
The grace of God he layd vp still in store,
Great grace that old man to him giuen had;
Well worthy doest thy seruice for her grace,
Vnworthy wretch (quoth he) of so great grace,
Then shall I soone, (quoth he) so God me grace,
And added grace vnto her excellence:
To tell this ruefull tale; thy sight could win thee grace.
But other some by gift of later grace,
To rest themselues, and grace to reconcile.
With sober grace, and goodly carriage:
Who with bold grace, and comely grauitie,
In her the richesse of all heauenly grace
And euery one her with a grace endowes:
So glorious mirrhour of celestiall grace,
Those same with stately grace, and princely port
She taught to tread, when she her selfe would grace,
For from my mothers wombe this grace I haue
At last such grace I found, and meanes I wrought,
And wanted grace in vtt'ring of the same,
And sith for me ye fight, to me this grace
Found no defect in his Creatours grace,
If then thee list my offred grace to vse,
Such grace now to be happy, is before thee laid.
Certes (said he) I n'ill thine offred grace,
For so great grace and offred high estate;
Of grace I pray thee, giue to eat and drinke to mee.
Of men, then beasts. But ï¿½ th'exceeding grace
An armed knight, of bold and bounteous grace,
Prince Arthur, flowre of grace and nobilesse,
Doth promise hope of helpe, and timely grace,
That he so wilfully refused grace;
Doth loose his dignitie and natiue grace.
She is the flowre of grace and chastitie,
Or grace of earthly Prince so soueraine,
Yet full of grace and goodly modestee,
And to her homage made, with humble grace:
And the strong passion mard her modest grace,
That neuer tasted grace, nor goodnesse felt,
That heauenly grace so plenteously displayd;
Receiued is to grace and new accord,
Ne like in grace, ne like in learned skill;
That had not grace thee blest, thou shouldest not suruiue.
That blushing to her laughter gaue more grace,
A sweet regard, and amiable grace,
The Prince of grace, to let him runne that turne.
Without regard of grace, or comely amenaunce.
For she was full of amiable grace,
Through his Heroicke grace, and honorable gest.
(For what doest not thou know?) of grace I pray,
Of thy great grace, and my great ieopardee,
For loe great grace or fortune thither brought
And gifts of heauenly grace he by him spide,
Mercy deare Lord (said he) what grace is this,
To make ensample of his heauenly grace,
Tempred with grace, and goodly modesty,
That all the gifts of grace and chastitee
The heritage of all celestiall grace.
Of grace and beautie noble Paragone,
Or quite deuourd her beauties scornefull grace.
I glad by any meanes her grace to gaine,
See how the heauens of voluntary grace,
She came in presence with right comely grace,
If goodnesse find no grace, nor righteousnesse no meed?
If good find grace, and righteousnesse reward,
Yet if that heauenly grace some good reliefe
Yet in that horror shewd a seemely grace,
For vnder maske of beautie and good grace,
Sith she her selfe was of his grace indigne:
Weend as he said, by that her outward grace,
Nepenthe is a drinck of souerayne grace,
Disgracing them, him selfe thereby to grace,
The controuerse of beauties soueraine grace;
Ah gentle Scudamour, vnto your grace
Graunt him your grace, but so that he fulfill
Both grace and gaine; but he in hell doth lie,
And euermore, when he did grace entreat,
Yet found no ease of griefe, nor hope of grace,
And him restore to former grace againe.
The gentle Squire recouers grace,
On him, whilst goodly grace she did him shew:
And wisht it were in her to doe him any grace.
The grace of his Creator doth despise,
An happie life with grace and good accord,
To win her grace his libertie to get.
By her committed be, of speciall grace,
But her the Prince through his well wonted grace,
And yet such grace is giuen them from aboue,
Vnworthy they of grace, whom one deniall
Yet she was of such grace and vertuous might,
And vnto Venus grace the gate doth open right.
Great Venus, Queene of beautie and of grace,
Shyning with beauties light, and heauenly vertues grace.
Whom when I saw with amiable grace
Adorn'd with honor and all comely grace:
A miracle of natures goodly grace,
And him entreat for grace, that had procur'd her paine.
And als' of princely grace to be inclyn'd thereto.
And readie to deserue, what grace I found.
Life, freedome, grace, and gifts of great auaile,
He wold by all good means he might, deserue such grace.
But by Gods grace, and her good heedinesse,
That Iustice was a God of soueraine grace,
And gan for grace and loue of her to seeke:
And soueraine grace, with which her royall crowne
Dealing of Iustice with indifferent grace,
But through high heauens grace, which fauour not
From thence pour'd down on men, by influence of grace.
She humbly thankt him for that wondrous grace,
Ten daies (quoth he) he graunted hath of grace,
Gins to looke vp, and with fresh wonted grace
And with the greatest purchast greatest grace:
Doth best become, and greatest grace doth gaine:
A goodly youth of amiable grace,
To Gods sole grace, whom she did oft implore,
And of her grace did stand againe assured,
With stayed steps, and graue beseeming grace:
Of which he grace and glory wonne alwaies,
Vpon her knee, intreating him for grace,
Whether such grace were giuen her by kynd,
Yet deckt with wondrous giftes of natures grace,
Adornd with goodly gifts of beauties grace,
For ioy of such good hap by heauenly grace.
That since by grace of God she there was sent,
Which she did more augment with modest grace,
That most in Pastorellaes grace did sit.
And when as Pastorella, him to grace,
Was fauoured, and to her grace commmended.
With grace from her, whose loue his heart hath sore engrieued.
Those three to men all gifts of grace do graunt,
Thy Loue is there aduaunst to be another Grace.
But whom they of them selues list so to grace.
And graced her so much to be another Grace.
Another Grace she well deserues to be,
All which she with such courtesie doth grace,
Through which if any grace chaunst to arize
Nathlesse Sir Bellamour, whether through grace
To weet what mortall hand, or heauens grace
The shield of Loue, whose guerdon me hath graced,
And darted forth delights, the which her goodly graced.
Enuiron'd with a girland, goodly graced,
And wish the heauens so much had graced mee,
That all he could, he graced him with her,
That with her goodly presence all the rest much graced.
Whether a creature, or a goddesse graced
And graced her so much to be another Grace.
This gracelesse man for furtherance of his guile,
Vngratious children of one gracelesse sire,
Much was he grieued with that gracelesse chaunce,
And saw that boasters pride and gracelesse guile,
And way did giue vnto their gracelesse speed:
And eke the Graces seemed all to sing,
Vpon her eyelids many Graces sate,
And vnto none my graces do enuye:
And with his goodly sisters, Graces three;
Of so great graces, as ye haue me shewd,
And all the Graces rockt her cradle being borne.
She with the pleasant Graces wont to play.
Was fostered by those Graces, (as they say)
For when as neither gifts nor graces kind
With whom those graces did so goodly fit:
Calidore sees the Graces daunce,
Or with the Graces there to play and sport;
Those were the Graces, daughters of delight,
They all are Graces, which on her depend,
For which the Graces that here wont to dwell,
In whom so many Graces gathered are,
Some shew of fauour, by him gracing small,
And who with gracious bread the hungry feeds,
Her gracious words their rancour did appall,
Whose glory is in gracious deeds, and ioyes
Whom gracious lot, and thy great valiaunce
Where gentle court and gracious delight
Soone as the gracious Alma came in place,
The gracious Numa of great Britanie:
In which a gracious seruant pictured
And comely glee of many gracious
From her faire eyes and gracious countenaunce.
Thy life she saued by her gracious deed,
She gracious Lady, yet no paines did spare,
Through gracious regard of her faire eye,
Of gracious speach, and skill his words to frame
So proou'd it eke that gracious God of wine,
And gracious speach, did steale mens hearts away.
There they awhile some gracious speaches spent,
These three on men all gracious gifts bestow,
And lying downe vpon the sandie graile,
And cast her colours dyed deepe in graine,
All arm'd with ragged snubbes and knottie graine,
Gramercy Mammon (said the gentle knight)
Gramercy Sir (said he) but mote I wote,
Old Styx the Grandame of the Gods, doth lay.
Thy fathers and great Grandfathers of old,
O thou most auncient Grandmother of all,
Of his great G[r]andmother with steele to wound,
Great Romulus the Grandsyre of them all,
But from the grandsyre to the Nephewes sonne,
Till that a Tyrant, which Grandtorto hight,
Therewith Grandtorto selfe I did appall,
As for Grandtorto, him with treacherie
Thy Gransire Nereus promist to adorne?
The Cle, the Were, the Grant, the Sture, the Rowne.
Did with strong hand withhold: Grantorto was his name.
Surprized was, and to Grantorto brought,
He with the great Grantorto fights,
And so be now Grantorto, who no lesse
Which message when Grantorto heard, full fayne
And eke Grantortoes worthy punishment.
And into her faire bosome made his grapes decline.
With their rude hands and griesly graplement,
Amongst the yron hookes and graples keene,
As two wild Boares together grapling go,
And creeping sought way in the weedy gras:
Till that at length she found the troden gras,
The verdant gras my couch did goodly dight,
And nought but pressed gras, where she had lyen,
And him beside there lay vpon the gras
And often bounding on the brused gras,
Besides them both, vpon the soiled gras
The gentlest knight, that euer on greene gras
That feeds on womens flesh, as others feede on gras.
And wilfully him throwing on the gras,
Through the greene gras his long bright burnisht backe declares.
And pour'd the purple bloud forth on the gras;
But as he lay vpon the humbled gras,
Nor any footing fynde for ouergrowen gras.
Whiles he had keeping of his grasing steed,
His grasping hold, and from her turne him backe:
One of his grasping feete, him to defend thereby.
His grasping hold: so lightly did vpstart,
And on the grasse her daintie limbes did lay
